div.head: YULETIDE
div.p: A certain Mr. Tusser ban gained a questionable kind of immortality by having left on record the fact that Christmas comes but once year; be insists that it should be everybody's delight to keep it up, and, in accordance, to make good cheer. At each recurrence of the festive season the remarks of the worthy Mr. Tusser find an ecbo in our hearts, although the delight is generally to be found in the opposite direction. There is upity at this period that anytbir.g attempted should be performed thoroughly, and we have yet to meet the man, who did not bear out in the proper spirit this excellent advice during the sentimental season of Christmas It is a strange and curious thing how the least sentimental of us become infected by the influence of Yuletide. It may arise from that eminent novelist Charles Dickens having toned with sadness his homely description of Xmas. In England he is inseparably connected with the great feast, and many are the families wbo at evening close the shutters, and gather round the crackling long upon the bearth, to bear once again tbe tale of Marley's ghost, and Gabriel Grub and the goblins. We do got object to this adulteration of the plampudding, anddook the watering our whisky, for it is right that in the midst of the season's peace and joy we should not lose sight of the lesson that Scrooge learnt that self is not the sole study in life The "Christmas Carol" is revived again to the delight of Mother's Meetings, and other humorous assemblies, to the joy of those ladies who love to let tall a silent tear. In Egypt we assume all the gaiety, bot feel little of the pleasure that Christmas brings. It can never be truly Christmas in a country, where the exile eats his plum-pudding in a temperature of 65 degrees. How many of us there are who drift back in the yesterday of things, when "Memory brings the light of other days" te cheer Cs. It is a happy thought that carries os back miles and miles across the sea to the old home, to feel again in spirit the joy that the body knows no more. Perhaps the happiest instinct that Christmas presents is in the recreation of our childish fancies. The snow capped hills ; the hanging up of the stocking on Christmas Eve for that benevolent old fellow, whom we thought supplied us with our toys; tbe delight with which the postman was hailed, the merry cound of the church-going bells. All crowd upon the memory to awaken the little feeling that we may bave left for the simple and innocent ideas with which youth endowed us We wonder now, in the light of recent events, if the old superstition of Father Xmas were correct, how many extra stockings would be requisitioned this year in Egypt. We must not lose sight of the joy in the rude awakening at midnight, wben the quivering sound of a superannuated cornet, beld by a trembling hand, would steal into our rooms breaking the silence of the night. How we appreciated the idea that it was not a tremble arising from sentiment which caused unnecessary trills in the music. There was the old bassoon, the still older piccolo, and other nuisances of a similar antiquity. Once the joy and pride of a defunct local band, the course of time had dealt even more severely with these men than with the well punctuated uniforms, which they wore, and which any admiral might once bave envied 0! what a talling off was there! Out in the wintry cold, freezing their instrumento beneath the local windows. What imperial noses they all had, lasting monuments to an everlasting thirst A more glowing tribute was never paid to the neighbouring distillery, than the presence of these Waits afforded. Their faces were as a sunset against the snow. Still they played on, until we fell asleep under the melodious strains of the "Miseltoe Bough", and dreamt of the morrow's delights. And the miseltoe bough! What little pleasantries bave been completed with thee as a pretext. But tbe cold print shall never reveal the recollections that we carry locked up in our bearts of pleasing moments beneath thy sheltering branches. Although the reality of Christmas may be absent in Egypt, we still bave memory to supply us with the missing ideals ; to recall the time honoured joke, the merry laugh, and the soul stirring tale, and, more than all, that great reunion, which bronght together the family, wbose members had dritted beyond their bome in the battle of life, meeting again year after year, when every minute detail connected with tormer gatherings was discussed with the same enthusiasm, as if in the matter of Xmas there were no such thing as past But how the grim reality presented contradictions to this feeling, wben, as each meeting succeeded the otber, some smiling lace would be missed. This is the sadness that intrudes upon our joy, but it is beautitul to stir the smouldering asbes into ftame, and to live again in the delusions of youth. Happy, happy, Christmas that can awaken our best instincts, and revive our dying sympathies.
ARTHUR S. DELANY.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: The Quarantine Board of Egypt has decided to apply cholera regulations against all arrivals from the whole coast of the Hedjaz.

div.head: Murder at Ibrahimie
div.p: The body of a young native woman was found yesterday in a ditch at Ibrahimieh. She had evidently met her death by strangulation.

div.head: Alexandria Municipality.
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Commission at 4 o'clock next Saturday afternoon. The sole topic of discussion will be the budget for 1908.

div.head: Customs Receipts.
div.p: The Custom House receipts from the 1st of January until the 21st inst totalled L.E. 3,678,460 as compared with LE. 3,426,569 during the corresponding period of 1906.

div.head: Execution
div.p: There will be a double execution at Hadra Prison on Saturday next, when Menais and Shanak, the murderers of the Omdeh of Bissentwai and of his friends will suffer the capital penalty.

div.head: Corporation of Western Egypt.
div.p: The Corporation of Western Egypt's Western Oases Railway has now reached the temporary terminus of North Kargeh and the 17th. January is fixed for the official opening of the line.

div.head: New Armenian Bishop.
div.p: Yesterday at the Catholic Armenian Church of the Immaculate Conception in Rue Averoff, Alexandria, the pastoral letter was read of the New Armenian Catholic Bishop of Egypt, Monsignor Bedros Vartabed Koyounian.

div.head: An Xmas Annual
div.p: We have received a copy of the fourth Xmas annual of the "Times of Ceylon." The cover is by Walter Crane, the well known English artist. Those interested in Ceylon could obtain copies of this interesting annual on applying to the Manager of the "Times of Ceylon" at Colombo It is indispensable to all who take an interest in that beautiful island.

div.head: Fire in Alexandria
div.p: At 8 o'clock on Christmas morning a fire broke out in Sharia Abou Doudar in a litho grapher's establishment The fire brigade on receiving the call were on the spot within a few minutes and, one hydrant sufficed to extinguish the fire after ten minutes' work. The damage was very slight. The fire was caused by a cigarette end having been thrown into a heap of waste paper.

div.head: Theft from the Semiramis.
div.p: An Abysinian groom at the Semiramis hotel was entrusted on Saturday last with the sum of L.E. 150 in order to pay for repairs or alterations which had recently been completed at the hotel. Some time after his departure from the hotel with the money, he returned with a cut on his cheek, and a tale of highway robbery. He affirmed that he had been attacked by some foreigners who had succeeded in making off with the bag containing the money. He was taken to the caracol where under the cross examination of the Mamour his story was found to be a fabrication from beginning to end. He was arrested, and we understand that the greater portion of the money has been found at his residence.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Viscount de Chamberet has arrived at Cairo on a mission from the Government of Tunis to study the agricultural position of Egypt and the various public and private institutions connected with agriculture here, On his return to Tunis he will present a report to the Government.

Among the arrivals at Alexandria by the Heliopolis" on Tuesday evening were Prince d'Arenberg, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Suez Canal Company, the Prince - Laza, Sir Thomas Lipton, Baron Empaill, the well known Belgian financier, Lord Villiers, Mr. Butler Aspinal, K.C., Sir William Bell, Count von der Burch, Captain, Mrs., Miss Beckwith. Countess Chamare, Barn Dramp. Count and Countess de Leasse, Major kineth Macdonald, Mrs. Macdnald, Mr. Carti Wiart, Count de Sonis, Sir Montagu Pollock, Orpbi Pasha, Captain Ponsonby, Mrs. And Miss Sinalino, Mr. T. E. and Mrs. C'eslagli Mr and Mrs. Giglio, etc.
It is announced that Mr. Mitchell Under Secretary of State at the Ministry of Finance, will shortly sever his official connection with the Egyptian Government service.

Sir Sumuel and Lady Sadler are among the visitors at Shepheard's Hotel His interests have always been centred round Middlesborough where he is a well known chemical manufacturer and coalowner for 32 years he acted as Member of the Tim Council there and between the years 1900 and 1906 he represented that town in Parliament having contested the seat unsuccessfully on three other Occasions.
The Khedive has conferred the Grand Cordon of the Medjidieh on Sir Horace Pinching, late director general of the Public Health Department.
Lt. Col. Cathcart Garner succeeds Mr. WP. G. Graham as sub director of the Public Health Department.

Mr. and Mrs A.O. Lamplough have arrived at Cairo from Alexandria and are staying at the Hotel d'Angleterre. Mr Lamplough will remain in Cairo for about a month, before going to l'pper Egypt, and will probably give a fortnight's exhibition of his pictures.

div.head: THE TRIPLE AGREEMENT
div.p: London, Tuesday

The "Globe" correspondent at Rome says that Menelik cannot resign himself to recognise the Anglo Franco Italian agreement. He re gards it in fact as non existent. The chie result of the triple agreement is to spread German influence in Menelik's country. Germany has already obtained many important concessions

div.head: SIR J. ARDAGH'S WILL
div.p: London, Tuesday
The late Sir John Ardagh's will shows a net personalty of £105,000.

div.head: MUSTRUS PASHA'S SUCCESSOR

div.head: THE NEW MAIL SERVICE
div.p: The new fast mail service has so far only benefitted Suakim to a limited extent. Instead of receiving all our mails on Sunday as formerly they now reach us in driblets, part arriving on Saturday morning by train from Port Sudan, while another portion, often containing the most important letters, arrives by steamer, generally the following day It would save a great quantity of legitimate annoyance and inconvenience if the postal authorities would look into this matter, and have it remerlied, for it must be due to lack of attention somewhere.

div.head: Suakim's Trade
div.p: The harbour presented quite a busy aspect on Monday with no less than five ships in port at once, which is ample evidence that the place is not being 'wiped out so rapidly as was anticipated Besides three of the Khedivial Co's. steamers calling on their regular itinerary, the SS. "Abbot ford" arrived with a full cargo of Coultrom England for the Sudan Government Railways. The SS. "Ahmadi" of the Bombay Persia Line arrived from Jeddah to discharge & mixed cargo of foodstuffs, merchandise, etc from India, chiefly consigned to Indian merchants, called Banyang. Much of the trade of Suakim, and other places in the Sudan, is in the hands of these merchants, especially four, dhurra, spices Cotton piece goods etc. They deal directly with the natives, and by cutting out the middleman are able to dispose of their commodities at a maximum of profit, with a minimum of expenditure, leaving little or no margin for competition from any European merchants. These Banyans live in even more frugal fashion that the native spend next to nothing on personal requirements, and all their earnings are sent to ludia. It is questionable whether such one sided trading can be considered advantageous to the prosperity of any country, more especially the Sudan, which would greatly benefit by a more reciprocal system of trading to ensure a better circulation of money in the country.

div.head: Price of Flour
div.p: Flour has attained an almost unprecedentedly high price here, going up within a short time from 100 PT 1 130) P.T. per kilo The scarcity of Hour in India is sure to keep the price up, but with a considerable consignment arriving by the "Ahmadi" it is expected to drop slightly within the next few days.

div.head: CHRISTMAS IN EGYPT
div.p: AT CAIRO

The comparison between Xmas at home and Xinas abroad has been worn so threadbare of late, that it is almost a surprise to realize the extent of the preparations that have been made in honour of the festival this week. There is scarcely an English home, hotel, or shop which bas not being kept busy in anticipation of the requirements of the season, and invitations, parcels, cards and messages of goodwill have been scattered broadcast through the land Xmas Eve was an exceptionally busy day, everybody was on the move, while shops and bars were being ransacked of their choicest Was A finely decorated tree was as usual in evidence in the Egyptian Hall at Shepheard's during the afternoon, many people dropping in there at tea time. During the evening it again became the centre of attraction for one of the usual dances was in progress and the opportunity was too good to be wasted. The floor was in perfect condition, and the well known Tzigane orchestra under took the latter half of the programme to the great delight of the dancers.Xmas morning was well on the way before the entertainment was brought to a close, and Xmas wishes were the last compliments paid to many as they turned their steps homeward. Another fine Xmas tree decorated the dining hall of Hotel d'Angleterre that saine evening, when a very special dinner was served to the guests as Fembled there, and a good programme of music enlivened the proceedings. Xmas day started early and the English Church was packed to its utmost capacity for the ordinary morning service, while other services had been performed earlier in the morning. Branches of palms and masses of flowers, poinsettias etc. replaced the ordinary decorations in favour at home, and gave a very beautiful effect to the editice. There was a great element of sadness in the service however for the minds of many were dwelling on the horror of the fatal accident which had occurred to the young chaplain of the Citadel, the Rev DP Miller, only a few hours earlier, to which allusion was made by the Rev. Hilton Molesworth in his sermon With the exception of this most sad occurrence, there has been nothing to mar the happiness of our Imus in Cairo. There have been cheery meetings on every side, and Xmas trees and Xmas dinners have been enjoyed by all, and though many of us are spending the season away from English homes and relatives we have had no occasion to regret the circumstance.
AT ALEXANDRIA

"East or West, Hame's Best". Despite our energetic efforts to carry out the traditions of the real old English Christinas, there is lacking in this country for many of us the family gathering which is the real secret of a merry Christmas. There are probably none ot 118 who Can altogether put sentiment aside at snch A season, and though we maintain with brave hearts that "Peace on earth, goodwill to all Mea", and make our Christinas a merry one, our thoughts are none the less bent towards that little island which rules the seas, and our j viality is somewhat forced Christmas in Alexandria was well spent, and the Briti-hers in Alexandria attended the services at the churches in large numbers. t StMark's five services were held on Christmas Day The total number of communicants WAY narkeilly larger than on Christmas Day last year, though the numbers at the late celebration were less At l'am. the church was tilled to over towing, and in addition to some 10 chairs placed in the church before the service, others were brought in from the chapel and the vestryA full choir rendered the choral parts of the service with precision and chciency which must have entailed much preliminary practising and careful attention Mr. Heaton presided at the organ, and the wolos in the anthem were taken by Miss Callender and Mr. W.E. Sarjeant, both of whom sang with much taste and teeling. The Te Deum WAS nung to a setting in D by Rev. E. Vine Hall. The anthem was "While Shepherds watched their flocks by night" by Joseph Burnley. The first of the offertory Sentence Let yourlight" wassung by the trebles to music by Rev. E. Vine Hall. During the collection the well known Christmas Hymn Adeste Fideles was sung most heartily by the congregation The Communion service wus Woodwant in E flat. In the sanctuary and west end of the church were placed palins and plants. The tont, lectern, pulpit and choir stalls were tastefully decorated with beautiful flowers and foliage. The vases placed upon the Holy Table in the church and in the chapel were filled with exquisite roses, lilies of the valley, and narcissi. Those responsible for the decorations were Mrs. Eyre, Mrs. Roberts, Mrs Algernon Ward, Mrs. Whitworth, Miss Garnett Botfield, Miss Coutes, Miss Roberts, Miss Spurgeon, Miss Talbot, and Mr. Macnee, Mr. Mustard and Mr. W. Mustard Among those who sent plants, foliage, and flowers were the following, Lady Blomfield, Mrs. Burton, Mrs. Callender, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Lawrence Dawson. Mme Debbane, My Dickson, Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Mrs. Pieton, Mrs. A S Preston, Mrs W T Smith, Mrs Tennant, Miss Batcheller. Miss Caloanni, Miss Coates, Mr. J. E. Cornish, Mr. Ebell, Mr Poster The Chaplain Archdeacon Ward), assisted by the Rev. J. Elkin, officiated at the services and the lessons were read by Rear Admiral Sir Masnie Blomfield KCMG, The collections throughout the day, were for the fund for the relief of the poor and amounted to PT 1390.5.

The hotels of Alexandria on Christmas night did their best to entertain their many guests The Savoy Palace gave a sumptuous dinner and the bandsome dining room was very well filled by tourists and residents. In the centre of the room was an electric lit and heavily burdened Christmas tree, but the coloured globes were almost eclipsed by the numerous tiny candles without which no Christmas tree could be complete. During and after dinner the orchestra of the hotel played an excellent selection of music, and Mr Brey, the popular manager of the hotel, did his utmost to make all forget that they were in a foreign land. The Christmas tree at the Khedivial Hotel was held on Christmas eve, and there were many on that night to celebrate the season, whilst last night a monster dinner was given. At the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh, the table was spread with liberal Christmas fare. Indeed no matter where one went Christmas greetings met the ear and Christmas liberality was showered upon one. Other notes on Christmas must be held over for to-morrow's issue.

div.head: A CARIO CONCERT
div.p: It is hardly fair or possible to judge the Société des Concerts or the orchestra by their second concert. The mainstay and crown of the program me, the music of the Forest Murmurs, had arrived too late and for Wagner was substituted – Weber. Really the change of programme did seem to affect the whole concert. Probably that one splendid piece might have attuned the whole orchestra and their conductor to the height of excellence which, understand they showed in the first concert. However that may be, there were dull moments. The Weber's invitation to the valse seemed hackneyed and noisy, and the long Mendlessohn savoured of a genteel drawing room The opening Mozart's "Zanber Hot" was charming and well given. What delightful clean strong music, full of character and delicacy. In the Italian symphony M. Baron rather emphasized and bur ried the Andante movement, and the orchestra hardly rose to the Presto, they did not "carry it off." But then it is deep beresy to say so. It always seems to me that Mendlessohn as a rule needy rather more than his due in interpretation and execution. The two Brabiny dances and the Bertroz. March were excellent. They showed what the orchestra could do especially in the march. "The Brahms dances perhaps require an exceptional display of temperament, if the fulness of the measure and changing rhythm are to be achieved. M Soubeyran sang correctly enough, but was a tritle hard and unsatisfying at mo nents. The next concert should be well worth hearing The programme is splendid ; and the orchestra apparently can "rise' to really good music, Gluck Handel, Wagner, what more can one ask, and probably Mlle Genevois for the songs. There was a good attendance, though one has to confess that some of the more fashionable representatives of Cairo culture were mclined to come in late and even to whisper at moments during the performance. It the Societé gives such excellent music, it should be rigid on that point,absolute silence and closed doors should be the rule I remember so well the severity of the Oxford Musical Club, and its fine of five shillings for the least sound-first offence only - subsequent offences almost ranked with fines for excessive speed of motor cars! Also the double curtain -if the hotel authorities will allow --it should be an improvement. At present any visitor or resident who finds himself or herself in the ball of the Semiramis, bas nearly as good a chance of bearing the music any of the sub cribers. These are paving ten frades a concert "The others need only reckon the price of their tea, and have the music thrown in?

div.head: KILLED BY A MOTOR CAR
div.p: ARMY CHAPLAIN'S DEATH

We very much regret to have to announce the death of the Rev. O P Miller, MA, B.Sc. Chaplain to the forces, which occurred, as the result of an accident, in the early hours of Christmas morning. It appears that Mr Miller who had been at the Citadel in the afternoon, went from there to Boulac by tramar and on slighting he was knocked down and run over by A motor car belonging to M. George Spezzaragoulos of the Splendid Bar Mr. Davey, of the Ordnance Office who happened to be passing immediately gave what assistance he could to the injured men, and despatched a messenger for medical assistance. Dr. Madden arrived about 10 minutes after the accident, Major Harding RAMC. and Bimbashi Thomson RUMO, following soon afterwards the Rev. R Armitage, D.S.O., and the Rev. J Hilton Molenworth, M.A., also arriving alert the same time Mr. Miller though terribly mutilated was still conscious, and was able to entrust me sages to his fellow clergymen. He was conveyed to Dr. Milton's Home, where he expired shortly after midnight. The Rev. Molesworth made touching references to the accident at the morning service, and the regret which he expressed finds an echo in the hearts of all who knew Mr. Miller. The inquest will be held at noon to-day, after which the funeral will take place.

div.head: PARIS-HOUSE GENEVA.
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

div.head: THE 1908 BUDGET
div.p: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE

We extract the following from the Financial Adviser's exhaustive note on the Budget for 1908 - However severely the crisis may have depressed certain branches of business, it has left untouched, and is, indeed, entirely disconnected from, the fundamental factors of Egyptian prosperity. Over-speculation followed upon that prosperity and has met with its penalty, but the mainspring of that prosperity, the country's inherent wealth intelligently developed, remains entirely unimpaired ; the crisis of 1907 is but an incident in a progress which is, humanly speaking, and in the absence of some political or natural convulsion, reasonably assured. Nevertheless this crisis has not been without its passing effect upon the public finances of the country; it has checked the growth of those items of the revenue, which, during the preceding period of general prosperity, showed the greatest elasticity. Both the import duties and the fees on the transfer of land, represent ing together about 21 millions of revenue, have, during the last few months, shown, in lien of the rapid increase of recent years, a slight diminution as compared with the corresponding period in 1906. In view of these results, it has been thought prudent to take, as regards 1908, & somewhat less sanguine view than usual of the probable growth of these revenues ; although the Customs return for November give some promise of recovery in the yield of the import duty Moreover, two items of former revenue disappear entirely from the receipts side of the new budget. The first is that derived from pay. ments to secure exemption from military service ("Badalieh.") Notwithstanding the somewhat unfavorable financial conditions of the moment, the Government is of opinion that the system of crediting these receipts to ordinary revenue should no longer be maintained. It is felt that these payments, which the richer part of the population are in a position to make in order to secure exemption from military service, should be employed for the benefit of their less fortunate brethren who serve as moncripts in the Army and Police. The details of the project are still under consideration. The receipts in question, however, will, from 1908, not figure in the ordinary budget, but be carried to a special fund to be devoted to the above mentioned purpose. The second item to disappear from the ordinary revenue is the proceeds of the sale of Government lands. The Government, apart from its liquid assets, possesses in these lands a large secondary reserve. It appears desirable that the proceeds of the sale of these lands, which have varied from LE 100,000 to L.E. 300,000 in recent years, should be carried to the credit of the Reserve Fund, and not, as heretofore, to ordinary revenue. At the same time, desirable as the change may be from the point of view of accounting, too much practical importance should not be attached to it, seeing that the surplus on the ordinary budget carried year by year to the credit of the Reserve has largely exceeded the amount of the receipts in question The elision of these two items from the ordinary budget of 1908 involves a loss of receipts which were estimated in 1907 to amount, in the case of Military exemption, to L. E 150,000 and in the case of sale of Government lands to LE 125,000 or in all to L E, 275,000. On the other hand, a welcome pew feature on the Receipts side of the budget is the payment by the Sudan Government of LE 45,000. as interest at 3 on L.E 1,500,000 ont of LE 3,300,000 advanced by the Egyptian Government up to the end of 1906 for Capital Expenditure. This payment has the effect of reducing the net sum to be paid by Egypt as contribution in aid of the civil budget of the Sudan in 1908 to LE 208,006 from L E. 253,006 in 1907. It is to be hoped that with The growing resources of the Sudan, it inay be found possible to lighten year by year this burden on the Egyptian budget The actual Revenue for 1907 is likely to reach the sum of L.E. 16 100.000 and the actual Expenditure L, E. 14,100,000, enabling A surplus of LE 1,704,000 to be carried to the credit of the Reserve. The unexpected balance of the Govern ment's Reserve, the Fund from which Capital Expenditure is met, was on the 31st October LE 7,772,336. Composed originally for the major part of the sums transferred to the Government by the Caisse de la Dette in compliance with the arrangement of 1904, this Fund is maintained mainly by the help of surpluses on the annual budgets, supplemented from time to time by exceptional receipts, such as that resulting from the liquidation of the Daira estates. For some years to come, and probably until 1912, no important additions to the Fund are to be expected apart from such as may result from surpluses on the ordinary budget. On the other hand, the amount expended out of the Reserve Fund in 1907 will reach nearly 44 millions, a rate of expenditure which it will be difficult to reduce to any great extent in the immediate future without injuriously restricting the development of the country In view of the above facts, and of the peculiar restrictions to which Egypt is subjected in the matter of borrowing, it is obvious that every endeavour must be made to maintain the Henerve by means of surpluses on the ordinary budget. Before passing from this subject it may be of interest to record the fact that the balance of L.E. 600,000, payable to the Egyptian Government on the final liquidation of the affairs of the Daira Sanieh, fell due for pay. ment towards the end of this year. In view of the prevailing financial stringency the Egyptian Government, in deference to urgent representations, has consented to the postponement of the payment of L E 500,000 of the above sim. By the arrangement arrived at with the Daira Sanieh Company this debt is transferred to the Crédit Poncier, which undertakes to discharge it in 4 years by equal instalments, paying 4% interest on the amount due. The instalments as received will be paid to the credit of the Reserve Fund. This arrangement, tantamount to the loan of half a million to the Crédit Foncier, involves considerable sacrifices on the part of the Egyptian Government, which, in order to meet the heavy expenditure on its Reserve Fund, is obliged to sell securities at a in ment when these are suffering from the general depreciation. It was assented to only in view of very exceptional circumstances which, it may be boped, will not recur in Egypt. The year, as regards the yield of cotton has been somewhat disappointing. Opening with brilliant prospects, final results have been unequal, and have not in many cases come up to expectation. The area under cotton was the largest on record, but the total yield is unlikely to exceed that of last year. The reasons for this are still somewhat obscure. The price of cotton has been satisfactory.

div.head:
OPERA IN CAIRO.
A TRIPLE BILL
div.p: "La Légende du Point d'Argentan". Cavalleria Rusticana" and the ballet from "Herodiade" were all three given on Monday night. But by a merciful dispensation the ballet came last of all, I take it as an answer to my prayers, as I was thereby able to evade it. "La Légende du Point d'Argentan" is a slight one act piece by one M. Pourdrain, produced only this year in Paris. The story is of a fisher couple, in great straits, the husband out of work, their child ill, and the wife striving in vain to recover the secret of the Argentan lace, and gain the prize for the Queen's robe. Her husband goes out through the storm to seek work, she remains at his work, a wanderer comes in to seek shelter and warmth. The wife relates her woes and hopes, and then tired out, falls asleep over ber task. The wanderer reveals herself. She is Our Lady -Herself, she summons ber Angels, who achieve the wondrous robe, and leave it for the wife to find when she awakes. The music is rather charming with a certain delicate and appropriate movement, a touch here and there of Massenet, and even, one would say, certain moments of Puccini. There were phrases and thirds of expression that distinctly suggested La Bobème". The mistake of the management was the cast. Those parts, slight as they seemed, should have been filled by the best singers available. The opera needs that. Mlle Talbert way too restrained, and hardly adequate, and the Wanderer was quite unable even to sing the music. M. Gorios, as the busband, had little enough to do. He did it well. The orchestra was good enough, but the performance as a whole was a tailore. 'Cavalleria" was the reverse Mme. Magne herself took the part of Santuzza, and was superexcellent all through it. Her acting was vivid and convincing, and her voice expressed to the last detail every shade of meaning the part could convey. M. Gorins again was torcible and accurate, thoroughly efficient. M. Flachat began badly. He seemed to be a trifle sharp in the prologue, and, thongh his ucting was good, rather too noisy and harsh in the church scene. But towards the end be showed the full beauty of his voice. The chorus again was excellent, especially the male voices. Of course the intermezzo was encored. It seems to have a relentless hold on Cairo taste. Still, it is a short episode, and taking the opera as a whole, Mine. Magne's singing and M. Flachat's finale were ample compensation for these lesser trials.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "FAUST"

After a lapse of many years the "Società Artistica d'Egitto" decided this season to include in the programme Gounod's masterpiece, the world wide favorite opera "Faust," and the production on Saturday night was altogether a distinct success. As Margherita, Signorina Ida Gobbato created a most favourable impression and her voice although not strong is of good quality and the many difficult passages allotted to the part were exceedingly well rendered. Signorina Gobbato, who is possessed of a charming presence, also exhibited histrionic ability, too rarely found on the operatic stage, which enabled her to present an altogether artistic impersonation. As Faust Signor Narciso Del Ry was fairly successful in this very trying rôle. We hope to see him to better advantage on some future occasion. Signor Carlo Walter is of course an old favorite, but bearing in mind his achievements last year in "Mefistofele" his performance on Saturday was a trifle disappointing. There was an absence of attention to detail which marked his previous excellent interpretation. His costume, too, appeared much too voluminous and handicapped him in certain effects. From a musical point of view his Mephisto was very acceptable, we think, however, that his rendering of the favorite old serenade left room for considerable improvement. The minor characters were unusually well supported, both Signorina Ida Pasotti as Siebel and Signor Oreste Benedetti as Valentino being excellent in their respective parts. The choruses showed considerable improvement on their previous performances. The ballet "La Notte di Valpurgis" was well executed and the orchestra under the guidance of Signor Zuccani was quite up to its usual standard.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
LIVERPOOL, December 12

A fair business has been done in Spot Egyptians, Brown cotton being raised to plb. whilst Uppers are reduced to plb. for Fair and Good Fair. In Futures & moderate business has taken place and the following are the latest quotations Dec. 9.55 Mar. 9.51 June 9.49 Sept. 9.46 Jan. 9.51 Apr. 9.49 July 9.45 Oct. 941 Feb. 9.58 May 9.49 Aug. 9.47 Mori 938 American Futures. The Market this week has been less active, and prices have had a declining tendency throughout. To day's closing values are 16@ 21 points below those of last Thursday, the distant positions having tallen more than the near. It is very difficult to form any definite opinion Money remains stringent, speculation is in abeyance, and there is some apprehension of trouble between the inaster spinners and the operatives in Lancashire, and this season of the year is generally nonenterprising : on the other hand Planters are holding firmly to their cotton and the most general estimates of the crop are round and about 11 to 12 million bales. The Ginners report froin the 1st to the 13th inst is to be published tomorrow, and is awaited with interest, as it should be indicative of either the smaller or larger estimates. Messrs. Neill's circular forecasts a consumption of 12,600,000, bales of American Cotton.

L'Administration a l'honneur d'informer le Public, qu'une enchère publique, par voie de Kaimat Mazad sera tenue le Samedi vingt-huit Décembre courant, aux Magasins de Gabbary À Alexandrie, à neuf heures du inatin, pour la vente des vieux articles et matériaux qui se trouvent aux dits Magasins ou on peut les exminer chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à midi, les Dimanches et jours féri: exceptés, et ce conformément aux Conditions de vente et à la noinenclature relatives à ces articles et matériaux qui peuvent être consultees an bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux à Boulac et à celui de l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary Alexandrie, Hux beures ci dessus indiquées Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette enchère devra, au préalable, verser à titre de dépôt provisoire une nomine de L E 5 Cinq Livres Egyptiennes) que l'enchérisseur declaruitjudicataire aura à parfaire jusqu'à concurrencedy 10% dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée et aura à enlever å ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés et ce dans les I lais indiqués dans la nomenclature en regard de chaque article, à compter de la date d'ac. centation de son oftre, les Dimanche et jours fériés exclus Les offres pourront etre faites sur papier timbré de trente millièmes si lintéressé ne pent pas assister aux enchères, et dans ce cas l'offre et le reçu constatant le versement du dépot provisoire seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommande à Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des (hemins de fer de l'Etat Gabbary Alexandrie et song double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante "Offre pour achat de Vieux Articles et Matériaux" Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement an jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés le sera pas prise en considération. L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 14 Décembre 1907

div.head:
FRANCE IN THE NEAR EAST.
THE EDUCATION PROBLEM

div.p: Senate. Mr. Blanchier asked Mr. Pichon to reserve a supplementary credit for 1909 for the Eastern schools. He said that England is tending to make Egypt a land of the English language, and added that in another five years the French section of the Khedivial law School would no longer exist. Mr. Genourier ? asked for the appointment of a parliamentary commission to examine the question of Eastern protectorates Mr. Pichop refused and pointed out the prosperity of the colleges of Beyrouth, Cairo, and Constantinople The Government desired to create a normal school in the East and will give subsidies to the lay founders in the East who actively assist the Republic.
(Havas)

In official circles the news published by certain anti German newspapers to the effect that Germany is the instigator of Turkey's action on the Persian frontier, is emphatically denied. Germany on several occasions, and notably at the commencement of the frontier dispute, in September 1906, advised Turkey to conclude with Persia a pacific arrangement The German Government's attitude with regard to the question has not changed up to the present.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE DENISHWAL PRISONERS.
RELEASE ON KHEDIVES ACCESSION DAY

div.p: It is announced that, with the consent of Great Britain, the Denishwai prisoners will be released on the anniversary of the Khedive's accession on 8th January
(Reuter)

The anti militarist Hervé has been sentenced to & year's imprisonment and to pay its fine of 3,000 francs for libelling and insulting the army and navy V. Merle, manager of the journal "La Guerre Sociale," and Almeres da member of the stuft, each have lieet sentenced to 5 years' imprisonment and to pay a tinent 3.000 francs.
(Reuter)

M. Pichon in the Senate reiterated that France did not wish to conquer Morocco. She was anxious only to pure prosperity in the countries of North Africa He Twelt on the advantage to France by the ententes with Great Britain, Japan, Spain, and Abyssinia in conjunction with the alliance with Russia. The friendly relations between her and Italy were daily strengthening. In reply to M Millaud he promised the introduce into Tunis the policy of sitting the natives with the Government of their country Admiral Cuverville urged the claims of the French schools in Egypt and Syria.
(Reuter)

The preliminary examination of Dim Zulu has begun. The son of the ret. I leadem baata gave evidence indicating that thuizin had made private preparations for arising in 1906 The Government has suspended with against Silwane and decided t telea rebels convicted last year. Th. ratinti in Zululand are ended Bambunt with evidence against Dini Zulu.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE VIBORG MANIFESTO.
TRIAL OF SIGNATURES

div.p: The trial has opened here of 169 signature of the Viborg manifesto. The accused are mostly labourites and constitutional democrats. They are charged with inciting the people to refuse to pay taxes and furnish recruits.
(Reuter)
The people are not reassured by the Shah's declaration and wish for practical fulfilment of his promises. Only a few shops are open. Armed men are reassembling. Random firing is heard
(Reuter)

The "Times" learns from St. Petersburg that the learling journals unanimously approve of the An.', Russian pacificatory mission in Persia, and record with satisfaction the ensuing improvement in the relations between the Shah and the Mejliss. Hope is expressed that a durable understanding will be reached.
(Reuter)

The Times" learns from Peking that an imperial edict in the name of the Empress repeats the desire that the throne should hasten the establishment of constitutional government, but threatens that should ir responsible agitation continue, the installation of this reform would be further postponed.
(Reuter)
The Cabinet has resigned in consequence of the rejection of the Army estimates framed by the Minister of War.
(Reuter)
Another 1,00.000 dollars worth of gold has been ordered
The Memphis Saving's Bank has closed its doors. Its deposits amount to 2,000,000 dollars
(Reuter)
The whole of Hedjaz is declared to be infected with cholera
(Reuter)
A decree fixes the date of the parliamentary elections at 5th April
(Reuter)
Cricket Victorians 459 runs for 9 wickets. The match was drawn.
(Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS
div.p: THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE
DEATH OF THE LEADER

We regret to announce the sudden death of Hassan Abdul Razik Pasha, the leader of the Party of the People and a member of the Legislative Council, which occurred yesterday morning in Cairo. He was an intimate friend of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdon, the Grand Mufti of Egypt, and he was in many respects an excellent sample of the enlightened Egyptian. The funeral, which was attended by a large number of mourners, took place yesterday afternoon in the Mosque of Iman el Sbafai. The following is the text of the political manifesto, addressed last week to tbe publie im England, by the late Hassan Abdul Razik Pasha. It appeared in the London "Standard" in the form of a letter to the Editor and is as follows: Sir,- Please allow me to express to you my sincere thanks for the kindly discrimination shown in your columns regarding the "Party of the People." May I take this opportunity of describing briefly the aims and organisation of the party in question, in order that the public in England may be more accurately acquainted with the real facts of the situation as they stand in Egypt. l'p till now, intelligent Egyptians have believed that the British occupation of Egypt was accidental, and that it would be removed when the causes that brought it about were removed. That belief is based on the conti dence which the Egyptians have in the promises of the British nation-a confidence which was made stronger still by the negotia tions that took place between Britain and Turkey in 1887 through Sir H. Drummond Woiff. Thus the Egyptians have silently watched the economical, moral, and political progress that has been effected in the country, in the full belief that, as soon as these reforins should be completed and based on solid ground, such as would justify for the Egyptians complete autonomy, and guarantee for. Great Britain and the rest of the European nations their respective interests, the management of the affairs of Egypt would then be entrusted to purely Egyptian hands, thereby tulfilling the words of the late Mr. Gladstone "Egypt for the Egyptians." The material progress achieved in Egypt during the last 25 years has been marvellous. But as yet there has scarcely been any real attempt at educational and political reform Education is still being carried on in such a manner as not to secure the desired results ; and in practice the representatives of the Egyptian nation are not given such privileges as are consistent with and adapted to Egypt's present social condition This has foubt aroused in the nation a certain degree of anxiety. The desire for progress in the direction of self-government led a number of Egyptian no tables, including a great number of the Le gislative Council and General Assembly, to hold a meeting, in which they decided to make every effort to secure the desired end, and established for that purpose a paper, "Al Ga ridah," to be their organ. These notables pab licly declared their principles, aims, and the means to attain them on September 21, 1907, a has already been reported to you by your Correspondent in ('airo. The number of these notables has now increased to 170 The aim of the Party of the People" is progress towards autonomy. Its means for securing that end are to make elementary education general, obli gatory, and free: to promote higher education, and to persuade the Government to acknow ledge the natural rights of the people by extending the jurisdiction of the Provincial Councils, the Legislative Council, and General Assembly in such a way as to produce effectual co-operation by the representatives of the people with the Government in public matters in order that the autonomy promised by the English may ultimately be attained. These, in short, are the views of the "Party of the People," and, I may add, of the best classes of Egyptian society. It is true there are some who seem to mistrust the English and to forget how advantageous it is to our political progress to preserve the best possible relations between Egypt and England. Fortunately, the influence of these people is practically limited to inexperienced youths, who, here as elsewhere, uphold extreme views. The organ of this party is "Al Lewa," and it calls itself the National party. Opposed to that party stands another that exists in little more than name. Its policy is to exalt the British Administration in Egypt, in season and ont of season, finding no fault whatever with it. "Al Mokattain" is the organ of this party, which calls itself the Liberal National party. What is of importance to all Egyptians, how ever diverse may be their views concerning reform, is to try to convince the British public of the fact that the existing Adininistration neglects higher edncation, that it has not looked favourably upon the university enter prise, and that it is not prepared to extend the Organic Law. All this is calculated to make for estrangement between the Egyptians and the British, which estrangement some mis taken enthusiasts use as a fertile ground in which to scatter those seeds of dissension which are hated alike by wise Egyptians and, so far as we can see, by wise Englishinen, too.

div.head: LITERARY HISTORY OF THE ARABS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir, Allow me to send you a copy of the last leaf, which is also a kind of conclusion, of a book just published "A Literary History of the Arabs" by Reynold A. Nicholson, M. A. Lecturer in Persian in the University of Cambridge and sometime Fellow of Trinity College The paragraph is entitled "Influence of European culture - Islam and Modern civilisation." If after reading it you think as I do, that it might do some good to your European and Oriental readers, especially now that there is so much talk about University and Moslem Congress, etc. you might perhaps be inclined to publish it in your wide spread and valuable paper.
Truly Yours,

Since Napoleon showed the way by his expedition to Egypt in 1798, the Arabs in that country, as likewise in Syria and North Africa, have come more and more under European influence the above mentioned Mobainmad Ali, who founded the Khedivial dynasty, and his successors were fully alive to the practical benefits which might be obtained from the superior culture of the West, and although their policy in this respect, was marked by greater zeal than discretion, they did not exert themselves altogether in vain. The introduction of the printing press in 1821 was an epoch-making measure. If, on the one hand, the publication of many classical works, which had well-nigh fallen into oblivion, rekindled the enthusiasm of the Arabs for their national literature, the cause of progress- I use the word without prejudice - has been furthered by the numerous political, literary, and scientific journals which are now regularly issued in every country where Arabic is spoken. Besides these ephemeral sheets, books of all sorts, old and new, have been multiplied by the native and European presses of Cairo, Bulaq and Beyrout. The science and culture of Europe have been rendered accessible in translations and adaptations of which the complete list would form a volume in itself. Thus, an Arab may read in his own language the tragedies of Racine, the comedies of Molière, the fables of La Fontaine, "Paul and Virginia" the Talisman' Monte Cristo' (not to mention scores of minor to mances, and even the Iliad of Homer The learned and purely technical literature derived immediately or indirectly from Europe 18 extensive. In short, France and Britain have taken the place which was oecupied in the Golden Age of Islam by Greece and India, but we must, I think, confess that down to the present day the results of all this activity amount to little more than the proverbial mouse Hitherto modern culture has only touched the surtace of Islam. Whether it will eventually strike deeper and penetrate the inmost barriers of that scholastic discipline and literary tradition which are so firmly rooted in the affections of the Arab people, or whether it will always continue to be an exotic and highly prized accomplishment of the enlightened and emancipated few, but an object of scorn and detestation to Moslems in general these are questions that may not be solved for centuries to come. Meanwhile the past affords an ample and splendid field of study. "Man lam ya'i'l ta'rikha fi sadrihi Lam yadri hulwa 'layshi min murrihi Wa man wa' akhbara man qad madà Adafa amaran ila umrihi He ill whose heart no History is enscrolled Cannot discern in life's alloy the gold, But he that keeps the records of the Dead Adds to his late new lives a hundredfold.

div.head: SUDAN MEDICAL DEPARTMENT, SUDAN.
div.p: NOTICE

The Sudan Medical Department is in need of the services of a qualified dispenser with pay commencing £16 per mensem Applications for this post will be addressed to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum They should be accompanied with all certificates, testimonials, references, etc., and with a duly filled up Application form which is obtainable (together with any information as to pay, increase of pay, conditions of service, etc.,) from the Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo A good knowledge of English and Arabic (reading and writing) is indispensable. The chosen candidate will be taken on probation for a period of two years.
